trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory Device Registration Overview| Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory Device Registration Overview| Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: is the foundation for device-based conditional access scenarios.
trans-unit.target: is the foundation for device-based conditional access scenarios.

trans-unit.source: When a device is registered, Azure Active Directory Device Registration provisions the device with an identity which is used to authenticate the device when the user signs in.
trans-unit.target: When a device is registered, Azure Active Directory Device Registration provisions the device with an identity which is used to authenticate the device when the user signs in.

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory Device Registration overview
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory Device Registration overview

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory Device Registration is the foundation for device-based conditional access scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory Device Registration is the foundation for device-based conditional access scenarios.

trans-unit.source: When a device is registered, Azure Active Directory Device Registration provisions the device with an identity which is used to authenticate the device when the user signs in.
trans-unit.target: When a device is registered, Azure Active Directory Device Registration provisions the device with an identity which is used to authenticate the device when the user signs in.

trans-unit.source: The authenticated device, and the attributes of the device, can then be used to enforce conditional access policies for applications that are hosted in the cloud and on-premises.
trans-unit.target: The authenticated device, and the attributes of the device, can then be used to enforce conditional access policies for applications that are hosted in the cloud and on-premises.

trans-unit.source: When combined with a Mobile Device Management solution such as Intune, the device attributes in Azure Active Directory will be updated with additional information about the device.
trans-unit.target: When combined with a Mobile Device Management solution such as Intune, the device attributes in Azure Active Directory will be updated with additional information about the device.

trans-unit.source: This allows you to create conditional access rules that enforce access from devices will meet your standards for security and compliance.
trans-unit.target: This allows you to create conditional access rules that enforce access from devices will meet your standards for security and compliance.

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory Device Registration is available in your Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory Device Registration is available in your Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: The service includes support for iOS, Android, and Windows devices.
trans-unit.target: The service includes support for iOS, Android, and Windows devices.

trans-unit.source: The individual scenarios that utilize Azure Active Directory Device Registration may have more specific requirements and platform support.
trans-unit.target: The individual scenarios that utilize Azure Active Directory Device Registration may have more specific requirements and platform support.

trans-unit.source: Read on to learn more about the specific scenarios that are available to you today.
trans-unit.target: Read on to learn more about the specific scenarios that are available to you today.

trans-unit.source: Scenarios enabled by Azure Active Directory Device Registration
trans-unit.target: Scenarios enabled by Azure Active Directory Device Registration

trans-unit.source: Azure AD Device Registration can be thought of as the foundation for a variety of scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Device Registration can be thought of as the foundation for a variety of scenarios.

trans-unit.source: In general, the service includes support for iOS, Android, and Windows devices.
trans-unit.target: In general, the service includes support for iOS, Android, and Windows devices.

trans-unit.source: The individual scenarios that utilize Azure AD Device Registration may have more specific requirements and platform support.
trans-unit.target: The individual scenarios that utilize Azure AD Device Registration may have more specific requirements and platform support.

trans-unit.source: These scenarios are as follows:
trans-unit.target: These scenarios are as follows:

trans-unit.source: Conditional Access to applications that are hosted on-premises: You can use registered devices with access policies for applications that are configured to use AD FS with Windows Server 2012 R2.
trans-unit.target: Conditional Access to applications that are hosted on-premises: You can use registered devices with access policies for applications that are configured to use AD FS with Windows Server 2012 R2.

trans-unit.source: For more information about setting up conditional access for on-premises, see Setting up On-premises Conditional Access using Azure Active Directory Device Registration.
trans-unit.target: For more information about setting up conditional access for on-premises, see Setting up On-premises Conditional Access using Azure Active Directory Device Registration.

trans-unit.source: Conditional Access for Office 365 applications with Microsoft Intune: : IT admins can provision conditional access device policies to secure corporate resources, while at the same time allowing information workers on compliant devices to access the services.
trans-unit.target: Conditional Access for Office 365 applications with Microsoft Intune: : IT admins can provision conditional access device policies to secure corporate resources, while at the same time allowing information workers on compliant devices to access the services.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see Conditional Access Device Policies for Office 365 services
trans-unit.target: For more information, see Conditional Access Device Policies for Office 365 services

trans-unit.source: Setting up Azure Active Directory Device Registration
trans-unit.target: Setting up Azure Active Directory Device Registration

trans-unit.source: The following settings are available for the Azure Active Directory Device Registration service:
trans-unit.target: The following settings are available for the Azure Active Directory Device Registration service:

trans-unit.source: Enable Azure AD Device Registration in the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: Enable Azure AD Device Registration in the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: Windows Devices discover the service by looking for well-known DNS records.
trans-unit.target: Windows Devices discover the service by looking for well-known DNS records.

trans-unit.source: You must configure your company DNS so that Windows 7 and Windows 8.1 devices can discover and use the service.
trans-unit.target: You must configure your company DNS so that Windows 7 and Windows 8.1 devices can discover and use the service.

trans-unit.source: You can view and enable/disable registered devices using the Administrator Portal in Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: You can view and enable/disable registered devices using the Administrator Portal in Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Enable Azure Active Directory Device Registration
trans-unit.target: Enable Azure Active Directory Device Registration

trans-unit.source: The following section describes how to enable the Azure Active Directory Device Registration Service for your directory.
trans-unit.target: The following section describes how to enable the Azure Active Directory Device Registration Service for your directory.

trans-unit.source: To enable Azure Active Directory Device Registration Service
trans-unit.target: To enable Azure Active Directory Device Registration Service

trans-unit.source: Log on to the Azure Portal as Administrator.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the Azure Portal as Administrator.

trans-unit.source: On the left pane, select **Active Directory**.
trans-unit.target: On the left pane, select **Active Directory**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Directory** tab, select your directory.
trans-unit.target: On the **Directory** tab, select your directory.

trans-unit.source: Select the **Configure** tab.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Configure** tab.

trans-unit.source: Scroll to the section called **Devices**.
trans-unit.target: Scroll to the section called **Devices**.

trans-unit.source: Select **ALL** for **USERS MAY WORKPLACE JOIN DEVICES**.
trans-unit.target: Select **ALL** for **USERS MAY WORKPLACE JOIN DEVICES**.

trans-unit.source: Select the maximum number of devices you want to authorize per user.
trans-unit.target: Select the maximum number of devices you want to authorize per user.

trans-unit.source: Enrollment with Microsoft Intune or Mobile Device Management for Office 365 requires Workplace Join.
trans-unit.target: Enrollment with Microsoft Intune or Mobile Device Management for Office 365 requires Workplace Join.

trans-unit.source: If you have configured either of these services, ALL is selected and the NONE button is disabled.
trans-unit.target: If you have configured either of these services, ALL is selected and the NONE button is disabled.

trans-unit.source: By default, two-factor authentication is not enabled for the service.
trans-unit.target: By default, two-factor authentication is not enabled for the service.

trans-unit.source: However, two-factor authentication is recommended when registering a device.
trans-unit.target: However, two-factor authentication is recommended when registering a device.

trans-unit.source: Before requiring two-factor authentication for this service, you must configure a two-factor authentication provider in Azure Active Directory and configure your user accounts for Multi-Factor Authentication, see Adding Multi-Factor Authentication to Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Before requiring two-factor authentication for this service, you must configure a two-factor authentication provider in Azure Active Directory and configure your user accounts for Multi-Factor Authentication, see Adding Multi-Factor Authentication to Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: If you are using AD FS with Windows Server 2012 R2, you must configure a two-factor authentication module in AD FS, see Using Multi-Factor Authentication with Active Directory Federation Services
trans-unit.target: If you are using AD FS with Windows Server 2012 R2, you must configure a two-factor authentication module in AD FS, see Using Multi-Factor Authentication with Active Directory Federation Services

trans-unit.source: Configure Azure Active Directory Device Registration discovery
trans-unit.target: Configure Azure Active Directory Device Registration discovery

trans-unit.source: Windows 7 and Windows 8.1 devices will discover the Device Registration Server by combining the user account name with a well-known Device Registration server name.
trans-unit.target: Windows 7 and Windows 8.1 devices will discover the Device Registration Server by combining the user account name with a well-known Device Registration server name.

trans-unit.source: You must create a DNS CNAME record that points to the A record associated with your Azure Active Directory Device Registration Service.
trans-unit.target: You must create a DNS CNAME record that points to the A record associated with your Azure Active Directory Device Registration Service.

trans-unit.source: The CNAME record must use the well-known prefix enterpriseregistration followed by the UPN suffix used by the user accounts at your organization.
trans-unit.target: The CNAME record must use the well-known prefix enterpriseregistration followed by the UPN suffix used by the user accounts at your organization.

trans-unit.source: If your organization uses multiple UPN suffixes, multiple CNAME records must be created in DNS.
trans-unit.target: If your organization uses multiple UPN suffixes, multiple CNAME records must be created in DNS.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you use two UPN suffixes at your organization named @contoso.com and @region.contoso.com, you will create the following DNS records.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you use two UPN suffixes at your organization named @contoso.com and @region.contoso.com, you will create the following DNS records.

trans-unit.source: Entry
trans-unit.target: Entry

trans-unit.source: Type
trans-unit.target: Type

trans-unit.source: Address
trans-unit.target: Address

trans-unit.source: enterpriseregistration.contoso.com
trans-unit.target: enterpriseregistration.contoso.com

trans-unit.source: CNAME
trans-unit.target: CNAME

trans-unit.source: enterpriseregistration.windows.net
trans-unit.target: enterpriseregistration.windows.net

trans-unit.source: enterpriseregistration.region.contoso.com
trans-unit.target: enterpriseregistration.region.contoso.com

trans-unit.source: CNAME
trans-unit.target: CNAME

trans-unit.source: enterpriseregistration.windows.net
trans-unit.target: enterpriseregistration.windows.net

trans-unit.source: View and manage device objects in Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: View and manage device objects in Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Administrator portal, you can view, block, and unblock devices.
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Administrator portal, you can view, block, and unblock devices.

trans-unit.source: A device that is blocked will no longer have access to applications that are configured to allow only registered devices.
trans-unit.target: A device that is blocked will no longer have access to applications that are configured to allow only registered devices.

trans-unit.source: Log on to the Microsoft Azure Portal as Administrator.
trans-unit.target: Log on to the Microsoft Azure Portal as Administrator.

trans-unit.source: On the left pane, select **Active Directory**.
trans-unit.target: On the left pane, select **Active Directory**.

trans-unit.source: Select your directory.
trans-unit.target: Select your directory.

trans-unit.source: Select the **Users** tab.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Users** tab.

trans-unit.source: Then select a user to view their devices
trans-unit.target: Then select a user to view their devices

trans-unit.source: Select the **Devices** tab.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Devices** tab.

trans-unit.source: Select **Registered Devices** from the drop down menu.
trans-unit.target: Select **Registered Devices** from the drop down menu.

trans-unit.source: Here you can view, block, or unblock the users registered devices.
trans-unit.target: Here you can view, block, or unblock the users registered devices.

trans-unit.source: Additional Topics
trans-unit.target: Additional Topics

trans-unit.source: You can register your Windows 7 and Windows 8.1 Domain Joined devices with Azure AD Device Registration.
trans-unit.target: You can register your Windows 7 and Windows 8.1 Domain Joined devices with Azure AD Device Registration.

trans-unit.source: The following topic provides more information about the prerequisites and the steps required to configure device registration on Windows 7 and Windows 8.1 devices.
trans-unit.target: The following topic provides more information about the prerequisites and the steps required to configure device registration on Windows 7 and Windows 8.1 devices.

trans-unit.source: Automatic Device Registration with Azure Active Directory for Windows Domain-Joined Devices
trans-unit.target: Automatic Device Registration with Azure Active Directory for Windows Domain-Joined Devices

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
